docs.abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on a child’s duty to severely injured parents and weighing aptitude against accommodations in student performance.
docs.snippet: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on a child’s duty to severely injured parents and weighing aptitude against accommodations in student performance.
docs.lead_paragraph: A little over two years ago, my family was involved in a catastrophic car accident overseas. My younger sibling was killed, and my parents survived but are severely disabled. My father is quadriplegic, while my mother has a traumatic brain injury resulting in severe cognitive impairment.

headline.main: What Do I Owe My Severely Disabled Parents?

docs.abstract: Fatigued by decision-making? Fuel up with a bialy.
docs.snippet: Fatigued by decision-making? Fuel up with a bialy.
docs.lead_paragraph: The dumbest place I ever had a panic attack was at brunch. On a sunny Saturday during a long weekend, sitting at the table with my friends, I took one look at the overlong menu, and it started: rapid heartbeat, sweating, that familiar sensation that I was definitely dying. I reported it to my therapist in detail a few days later, and she told me it was most likely situational stress, triggered by feelings of discomfort.

docs.abstract: I learned how to take candy tasting as seriously as wine tasting. What I discovered surprised me.
docs.snippet: I learned how to take candy tasting as seriously as wine tasting. What I discovered surprised me.
docs.lead_paragraph: I learned how to take candy tasting as seriously as wine tasting. What I discovered surprised me.

headline.main: Flavor Is a Language, and Like Wine, Candy Has Its Own

docs.abstract: The “Moonlight” director brings his intuitive approach to an adaptation of James Baldwin’s “If Beale Street Could Talk.”
docs.snippet: The “Moonlight” director brings his intuitive approach to an adaptation of James Baldwin’s “If Beale Street Could Talk.”
docs.lead_paragraph: The “Moonlight” director brings his intuitive approach to an adaptation of James Baldwin’s “If Beale Street Could Talk.”

headline.main: Barry Jenkins’s Films of Love, Pain and Black Male Vulnerability

docs.abstract: At a retrospective at the Whitney Museum, the life and work of the artist and AIDS activist are a model for making art out of political anger.
docs.snippet: At a retrospective at the Whitney Museum, the life and work of the artist and AIDS activist are a model for making art out of political anger.
docs.lead_paragraph: If you know one work by David Wojnarowicz, it is probably “One Day This Kid,” a black-and-white self-portrait of the artist as a prepubescent, surrounded by text. This kid is wearing suspenders and a gee-whiz face, all forehead and chin and two buck teeth. His ears stick out like satellite dishes. It’s the early ’60s, and Wojnarowicz looks as if he walked into the Sears photo studio directly from the set of “Leave it to Beaver.” Then you read the words.

headline.main: The Rage and Tenderness of David Wojnarowicz’s Art

docs.abstract: His wild, profane creations confront us with everything horrifying and joyous about America — and ourselves. Now he’s coming for Broadway.
docs.snippet: His wild, profane creations confront us with everything horrifying and joyous about America — and ourselves. Now he’s coming for Broadway.
docs.lead_paragraph: Imagine that you’re sitting in a theater, that you’ve been sitting there for 19 hours, with five more to go. Well, not only sitting. At times, you’ve been asked by the show’s maestro and star, the drag queen and performance artist Taylor Mac, to dash across the room to re-enact the Oklahoma Land Rush, or in a ritualized recompense for white flight, to “move to the suburbs” by surrendering your coveted orchestra seat to someone who was stuck in the back. You’ve grown used to the surprises of this piece, a 24-hour-long concert in which Mac works his way through 246 songs that were popular in America from 1776 to the present, interspersed with a radical narrative of American history. You came expecting that you would be challenged, provoked, entertained — why else sign up for a full-day, participatory history lesson administered by a queen who is currently wearing a macramé owl with a yellow-brick tail (a homage to Judy Garland and the Stonewall riots), a sequined miniskirt, a camouflage cape with cutout psychedelic peace signs and an iridescent Afro/space helmet? — but you aren’t prepared for what comes next.

headline.main: Taylor Mac Wants Theater to Make You Uncomfortable

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: Gary: A Sequel to Titus Andronicus (Play)

docs.lead_paragraph: Romeo and Juliet in 21st-century America is no simple narrative. While Javier Zamora’s lovers may not have to contend with feuding families nor navigate the ethnic minefields of “West Side Story,” their destinies are star-crossed nevertheless. As they embark on their first date, the shadow of exile — to lose a homeland and not feel quite welcome in the new one — sweeps over them. No hands are held yet, no kisses dared; yet they dream of love, what might grow from borrowed ground. Selected by Rita Dove

docs.abstract: The man had fever, chills and aches in the midst of a flu outbreak. It turned out he had a very different kind of infection.
docs.snippet: The man had fever, chills and aches in the midst of a flu outbreak. It turned out he had a very different kind of infection.
docs.lead_paragraph: “I think I’m losing this battle,” the 58-year-old man told his wife one Saturday night nearly a year ago. While she was at the theater — they’d bought the tickets months earlier — he had to crawl up the stairs on his hands and knees to get to bed. Terrible bone-shaking chills racked him, despite the thick layer of blankets. The chills were followed by sudden blasts of internal heat and drenching sweats that made him kick off the covers — only to haul them back up as the cycle repeated itself.

headline.main: All His Symptoms Pointed Toward the Flu. But the Test Was Negative.
headline.print_headline: All His Symptoms Pointed Toward the Flu. But the Test Was Negative.

docs.abstract: After serving time for a crime I committed at 16, I discovered how hard it is for a felon to get a second chance.
docs.snippet: After serving time for a crime I committed at 16, I discovered how hard it is for a felon to get a second chance.
docs.lead_paragraph: One afternoon in the fall of 2016, I sat in a windowless visiting room at the Manson Youth Institution in Cheshire, Conn. A recent graduate of Yale Law School, I was a certified legal intern on a fellowship in the New Haven public defender’s office. J., a lanky 18-year-old brown-skinned kid sitting across from me, was my first client. He didn’t talk. Instead he stared at me as if I were the police. Sanford O. Bruce III, my supervising attorney, listened as I explained to J. (one of his initials) what we knew of the charges against him. A young man with whom J. attended high school had claimed that J. and another kid he didn't know had threatened him with a pistol, then robbed him of his cellphone and a couple of hundred dollars. Officers arrested J. minutes later, but the other suspect, who supposedly held the gun, was never found.

headline.main: Could an Ex-Convict Become an Attorney? I Intended to Find Out

docs.abstract: Diplomat cream and pâte à choux combine in a delicacy that will bring you joy.
docs.snippet: Diplomat cream and pâte à choux combine in a delicacy that will bring you joy.
docs.lead_paragraph: I’ve enjoyed some electric spikes of optimism and even some exhilaration over the past many months, but they’ve ended like junk-food highs; generally, I’ve found myself feeling uncommonly bleak. I try to tune it out, look to the light, but even the food pages have grown heavy. Where there used to be lively essays about delicious and interesting foods, you now find recipes asked to carry great freights, the poor little plate of food and the dinner table itself working overtime to fix the earth, the children, the wars, addiction, drinking water, wildfires, earthquakes, obesity and family dysfunction. I’ve been guilty of this myself.

headline.main: Now Is the Time for the Comfort of Swan-Shaped Pastries
